designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2011 country programming mission the Government of the People’s Republic 
of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for technical assistance (TA) to 
develop  innovative  financing  structures  for  urban  infrastructure  and  municipal  services  in 
Harbin  Province.  Following  detailed  consultations  during  8–13  March  2012  with  the 
Heilongjiang Provincial Finance Department and the Harbin Municipal Finance Bureau, a TA 
fact-finding  mission  on  11–12  April  2012  discussed  and  agreed  on  the  objectives,  scope, 
implementation arrangements, costs, and terms of reference of the proposed TA. The design 
and monitoring framework is Appendix 1.1 
 
 2.  The TA will strengthen the capacity of Harbin’s municipal financing mechanisms to enable 
the Harbin municipal government to finance infrastructure and services growth and ensure long-
term economic health. The TA will complete analyses of the municipality’s current fiscal health; 
local government investment vehicles (LGIVs); infrastructure financing needs and options; and new 
ideas for financing municipal needs including taxes, bond issuance, and public–private partnership 
(PPP).  Based  on  the  studies,  final  recommendations  revising  investment  programs  and  the 
revenue base will be provided.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 3.  In the PRC, municipal debt systems were revised during the tax reforms of 1994. These 
changes split the tax base into national, shared, and local taxes. National taxes currently include 
customs duties, income taxes on national firms, and consumption taxes. Shared tax revenues 
come from value-added tax, corporate and personal income taxes, and securities transaction 
taxes, and these are shared with local governments under varying ratio arrangements. Local 
taxes include sales taxes and land taxes (currently under pilot). The result of this change has 
been  to  shift  revenues  away  from  local  governments  to  the  central  government.  With 
accelerated urbanization and the demands of an export-oriented high-growth economy, local 
governments  have  found  themselves  under  significant  pressure  to  provide  infrastructure—
pressure that was exacerbated by the global financial crisis that began in 2007.2 
 
4.  In 2010, local governments in the PRC accounted for over 80% of public spending, but 
only 45% of the country’s tax revenues were provided for use at the municipal level. This 
difference between spending and revenue is around $600 billion or 10% of the gross domestic 
product in 2010. To fill this gap, local governments have relied in the past on income generated 
from land sales and LGIVs as additional funding sources.  
 
5.  In July 2011, the National Audit Office released its National Audit of Regional Finances 
report, highlighting the extensive debt of CNY10.7 trillion issued by local governments, including 
LGIVs that circumvented borrowing rules. The report indicated that 6,576 LGIVs set up by the 
end  of  2010  held  an  estimated  CNY8.5  billion  in  bank  debt,  at  least  60%  of  which  local 
governments have the responsibility to repay. Given these figures, and findings that portions of 
this debt were uncollateralized and not guaranteed by the central government, the government 
is currently reforming municipalities’ use of LGIVs.  
 
6.  The slowdown in the real estate market is restricting the ability of local governments to

raise  funds.  During  the  real  estate  market  boom  since  2005,  local  governments  became 
dependent on land sales to generate budget revenues. The current slimming of the property 
market is now eliminating that option. According to Centaline, a major real estate broker, more 
than 100 land auctions across the country failed in November 2011. As many of the LGIVs were 
backed by state land, the shrinking real estate market not only limits future cash inflows but also 
reduces local governments’ ability to pay debt obligations incurred during the global financial 
crisis.  
 
7.  In response to lower revenues, Shanghai, Chongqing, and other cities began imposing 
taxes in 2011 on large single family homes, high-end flats, and second homes and apartments. 
In theory, such taxes are an excellent source of revenue for these cities, but in practice these 
taxes have yielded little revenue. As an example, the property tax rate in Chongqing is 0.5%–
1.2% of estimated value and is levied on only about 8,500 properties, despite there being 
126,000 second homes in Chongqing listed by the National Statistics Bureau at the end of 2011. 
Such a limited target group meant the tax generated less than 0.2% of Chongqing’s tax revenue 
for the year. The effort nevertheless demonstrates a willingness to explore new methods of 
generating revenue. Other experiences, such as the recent evaluation of the Shanghai–Pudong 
bridge and road tolls, show the importance of balancing revenues with development needs, and 
of considering both core funding and tolls where public goods benefits exist.    
 
8.  The 12th Five-Year Plan for National Economic and Social Development, 2011–2015 
calls for further infrastructure development implemented by municipalities to sustain rapidly 
increasing urban populations. New financing mechanisms must be studied and developed at the 
municipal level to ensure long-term fiscal health and sustainability. Specific issues faced by 
local municipalities include heavy reliance on bank loans and indirect finance channels, lack of 
appropriate governance over ever-expanding government-backed investment units, and having 
to work within a framework of outdated government finance policy.  
 
9.  Emerging pressures and desire for financial reform provide an excellent opportunity for 
municipalities to take three important steps. The first step is to take stock of the current situation 
and  arrangements,  assess  urban  infrastructure  needs  and  the  creditworthiness  of  local 
municipalities, and identify immediate measures. The second step is to explore alternative 
sources of financing, review regulatory frameworks, and consider how to appropriately generate 
resources at the municipal level to meet current and anticipated needs. As there is also a desire 
for institutional reform, it is possible to review and diversify government-led investment bodies 
and further promote business operations such as PPPs. The third step is to start analysis and 
discussion of financial flows between municipal government and other levels of government, to 
improve  understanding,  use  these  funds  more  efficiently,  and  better  monitor  results  and 
accounting for these funds.   
 
10.  Heilongjiang  developed  a  provincial  development  strategy  under  the  TA  Provincial 
Development Strategies for Two Northeastern Provinces.3 In this strategy, there are specific 
targets  for  Harbin  municipality,  recognizing  that  the  municipality  generates  two-thirds  of 
provincial  gross  domestic  product.  These  include  developing  Harbin  as  an  axis  for  a  key 
economic zone for export and as a pillar for industrial development. The proposed strategy 
places significant responsibility on Harbin to provide connecting infrastructure and capacity for 
trade with the Russian Federation and in the North Asia region. It also mentions the importance

of Harbin developing an efficient and effective real estate market. Accordingly, it is critical that 
the municipality be able to address in-migration and related services, expand infrastructure, and 
coordinate with the provincial government and other local governments.  
 
11.  Harbin municipality consists of the eight urban districts of Harbin, three satellite cities, 
and seven rural districts. The urban population is expected to reach 65% of the total by 2016, up 
from 55% at the end of 2010, adding over 1 million people to the city. To help manage expected 
growth, the city is currently implementing a master plan entitled Further Developing the Northern, 
Southern, and Central Parts of Harbin Municipality as Well as the Affiliated Counties, to ensure 
the development of key infrastructure. The Harbin municipal government is working to find a 
balanced way to ensure capital inflows and reforming its current financial mechanisms to ensure 
long-term fiscal vitality. This TA will provide a localized opportunity to address the financing 
issues confronting Harbin and a larger opportunity to find solutions that can be applied across 
the region and the country. 
   
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The impact of the TA will be the strengthened capacity of local governments to manage 
municipal finances. This strengthened capacity will contribute to smooth economic growth and 
help provide jobs and increased social services for low-income households migrating into the city 
from rural areas. The outcome will be a deepened municipal financing mechanism for Harbin to 
enable the Harbin local government to finance growth and ensure long-term economic health.  
   
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 13.  The TA will consist of five components: (i) an analysis of current fiscal health; (ii) a review of 
LGIVs, including a case study; (iii) a review of new concepts for innovative and sustainable 
financial structures, including a study tour to develop awareness of good infrastructure financing 
practices used by other high-growth cities; (iv) assessment of specific financing options for urban 
infrastructure development; and (v) the development of knowledge products for each of these 
components.  
 
14.  The TA will deliver five major outputs, with the following work to be done:  
 
(i)  Analysis  of  the  current  fiscal  health  of  Harbin  municipality.  Review  the 
municipality’s current modes and issues of financing, debt obligations, and financial 
structures with a focus on infrastructure financing through site visits, meetings with 
government agencies, and document review. Make specific recommendations for 
immediate actions to improve the financial structures and status of the municipality. 
(ii)  Review and recommendations for improving government-backed investment 
units, including a case study. Complete a detailed review of a selected LGIV as a 
case study and summarily assess data on other LGIVs. Make policy suggestions for 
improving the implementation and reform of governance, transparency mechanisms, 
and the financial management of current government-backed investment units to 
promote  financing  efficiency  toward  increasing  future  urban  infrastructural 
construction. 
(iii)  Assessment  and  recommendations  for  improved  municipal  revenue 
arrangements.  Review  existing  revenue  sources  and  financing  channels  and 
identify new ones. Propose sustainable institutional structures that address the

4   
financial  context  of  the  municipality  based  on  international  good  practice. 
Specifically, focus on the steps necessary to be selected by the central government 
as an experimental site for municipal bond issuance. In addition, review current 
concepts  of  revenue  sharing  between  the  local  and  central  governments  and 
identify the potential for long-term revenue-sharing agreements. Assess asset and 
liability structures and provide recommendations. Review and provide advice on 
improving credit appraisal and rating processes. 
(iv)  Recommendations  for  new  and  innovative  financing  of  infrastructure 
development. Propose innovative mechanisms, policy suggestions, and affiliated 
action plans including a detailed focus on PPP or other sustainable and practicable 
mechanisms that will financially support the city’s infrastructure master plan and 
address  long-term  financing  demands.  To  promote  understanding  and  further 
broaden views on specific municipal financing tools, conduct an international study 
tour under this output. 
(v)  Synthesis paper and knowledge products. The TA will produce a synthesis 
paper with all four of the areas above blended into an action plan, as well as four 
stand-alone reports, one for each of the previous four outputs. In addition, the TA 
will sponsor local workshops to present to various stakeholder groups the study 
results and policy implications.  
 
15.  Targeted workshops will be organized for different stakeholders at various stages of project 
implementation,  including  an  inception  workshop,  an  interim  workshop,  a  draft  final  report 
workshop, and perhaps others. All workshops are expected to be attended by an ADB mission, 
government officials, LGIV representatives, and specialists in relevant fields to ensure the inclusion 
of diverse views and the wide dissemination of project outputs. The executing agency and the 
implementing agency will ensure that all finalized reports and recommendations are circulated 
across all relevant provincial and municipal departments and agencies.  
   
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $640,000, of which $400,000 which will be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The 
government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office,  office 
supplies, domestic transportation, and other in-kind contributions. Detailed cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. The executing agency has agreed to make other direct 
contributions if needed, covering all workshop and international study tour costs in excess of the 
TA’s budgeted allocation.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The TA will begin on 1 September 2012 and end on 31 December 2014, for a total of 28 
months. The Harbin municipal government will act as the executing agency for the TA. The 
Office of Financial Affairs of the Harbin Municipal Finance Bureau will be the implementing 
agency. In addition, the Harbin Municipal Economic Research Institute and the Harbin Municipal 
Investment Promotion Bureau are expected to provide support and input to further guide the 
work. All proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in accordance with the Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
18.  The TA will engage four national consultants for a total of 20 person-months and an 
international consultant for 4 person-months. The consultants will be responsible for producing 
the  TA  outputs  and  deliverables  effectively  and  on  time,  consistent  with  the  design  and

5 
monitoring framework, and for organizing and carrying out all TA activities including surveys, 
field visits, training, and workshops. Consultants for the TA project will be individually engaged in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
19.  All consultants’ reports will be provided in both English and Chinese. The consultants will 
maintain close working relations with ADB, the Harbin Municipal Finance Bureau, and the 
Harbin Municipal Economic Research Institute and will regularly discuss project progress and 
findings. Meetings involving the consultants, ADB staff, the Harbin Municipal Finance Bureau, 
and the Harbin Municipal Economic Research Institute will be held to provide guidance to the 
consultants, and to review their reports. 
 
20.  The international study tour will focus on high-growth cities that have successfully made 
infrastructure investments while ensuring the fiscal health of their budgets. The study tour will be 
conducted  before  the  preparation  of  the  draft  final  report,  and  the  related  output  will  be 
incorporated in the draft final report for review.  
 
21.  The executing agency, in consultation with the implementing agency, will supervise the 
day-to-day work of the consultants and take responsibility for administering national training 
programs, seminars, workshops, and international study tours. ADB will assist the executing 
agency  in  overall  TA  operations,  monitoring,  facilitating  international  study  tours,  and 
disseminating knowledge  results.  Knowledge  products  will  be  disseminated  in the  planned 
workshops and conferences, on executing agency and ADB websites, and with hard copies 
made available to stakeholders during and after events. The project-specific indicators and 
targets in the design and monitoring framework will be monitored by the executing agency with 
ADB support. Policy dialogue will be maintained with the government, and project-specific 
issues  will  be  taken  up  with  government  counterparts  during  review  missions.  Technical 
milestones will be monitored in reports to be prepared by the consultants.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  Innovative  Financing  for  Urban 
Infrastructure and Municipal Services in Harbin, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Implementing the policy and advisory technical assistance will require 20 person-months 
of national consultancy and 4 person-months of international consultancy. Consultants will be 
hired  individually  in  accordance  with  Asian  Development  Bank’s  Guidelines  on  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The team leader and the international public 
finance  specialist  will  be  responsible  for  the  quality  and  timely  completion  all  outputs.  All 
consultants will work under the coordination and monitoring of the ADB project officer, who will 
ensure complementarity and cohesion in their activities.  
 
2.  The consultants will produce seven reports: (i) an inception report outlining a full work 
plan, (ii) a report identifying and analyzing current fiscal issues faced by Harbin municipality, (iii) 
a case study of a representative local government investment vehicle (LGIV), (iv) a white paper 
outlining recommendations on governance and financial management over current government-
backed investment units, (v) a white paper outlining recommendations for further financing 
infrastructure development, (vi) a white paper outlining recommendations on innovative and 
sustainable local government financing structures, and (vii) a summary report. 
 
A.  Team  Leader  and  Municipal  Finance  Specialist  (national,  9  person-months, 
intermittent) 
3.  The objective of this consultant is to lead the team toward completing all outputs of the 
technical assistance in an effective, efficient, collaborative, and timely manner. The scope of 
work involves team leadership, work direction, and stakeholder engagement. The consultant will 
analyze  and  suggest  improvements  to  public  sector  generation  of  revenue,  financing  of 
infrastructure, management of local government investments, and entering into public–private 
partnership (PPP) for infrastructure development. The consultant will have a master’s degree in 
public  finance,  economic  development,  or  other  relevant  field  and  strong  expertise  and 
experience in public finance, particularly in (i) budget management, (ii) regulatory frameworks, 
(iii) asset management, (iv) taxation, (v) credit appraisal, and (vi) infrastructure financing. The 
consultant must also have detailed understanding of the fiscal and economic growth issues 
facing Harbin, as well as detailed understanding of central government financing policy. In this 
regard, the consultant must have at least 10 years of experience working on municipal finance 
issues. As team leader, the consultant must have demonstrated outstanding organizational 
performance and be proficient in English. The specific responsibilities of this consultant will be 
to:  
(i)  serve as the team leader of the national and international consultants and ensure 
the timely completion of the pilot project design; 
(ii)  prepare a detailed inception report to achieve the outputs of the project, which 
will indicate the target person-days and timing of each task;  
(iii)  collaborate directly with the international consultant on all outputs to ensure the 
quality and timely completion of all research outputs; 
(iv)  lead and manage all daily activities and act as a direct liaison for the project with 
local counterparts; 
(v)  review  the  municipality’s  current  modes  of  financing,  debt  obligations  and 
financial structures and oversee the drafting of a summary report highlighting key 
areas for focus as per output 1 in Appendix 1; 
(vi)  conduct  research  to  identify  new  and  acceptable  ways  for  the  municipal 
government to generate revenue such as bond issuances and local taxes, and 
oversee a draft report outlining all findings;

(viii)  review the status of government-backed investment units; propose a suitable

(ix)  review the current framework for PPP and determine what further actions are

B.  Municipal Finance Specialist (national, 5 person-months, intermittent)  
4.  The consultant will have a master’s degree in public finance, economic development, or 
other relevant field or equivalent experience, as well as strong expertise and experience in 
public finance,  particularly  in  (i)  budget management, (ii) regulatory frameworks,  (iii)  asset 
management, (iv) taxation, (v) credit appraisal, and (vi) infrastructure financing. The consultant 
must also have detailed understanding of the fiscal and economic growth issues facing Harbin, 
as well as detailed understanding of central government financing policy. In this regard, the 
consultant  must  have  at  least  10  years  of  work  experience  on  provincial  finances.  The 
consultant should be proficient in English. The specific responsibilities of this consultant will be 
to: 
 (i)  work directly with the team leader and international consultant to review the 
municipality’s  current  modes  of  financing,  debt  obligations,  and  financial 
structures and draft a summary report highlighting key areas for focus; 
(ii)  conduct  research  to  identify  new  and  acceptable  ways  for  the  municipal 
government to generate revenue, such as bond issuances and local taxes, and 
draft  a  report  outlining  all  findings,  written  jointly  with  the  team  leader  and 
international consultant as output 4 in Appendix 1; 
(iii)  review  current  concepts  of  revenue  sharing  between  the  local  and  central 
governments and identify the potential for long-term revenue-sharing agreements;  
(iv)  lead the case study; review the status of government-backed investment units; 
propose  governance,  transparency  mechanisms,  and  financial  management 
mechanisms  for  implementation  in  consultation  with  the  team  leader  and 
international consultant; and draft a report with findings and recommendations as 
output 2 in Appendix 1; and 
(v)  propose  recommendations  on  how  to  enhance  credit  appraisals  and  ratings 
toward further promoting fiscal soundness and engaging investors, and present 
conclusions in a report that is written jointly with the team leader and international 
consultant. 
 
C.  Infrastructure Financing Policy Specialist (national, 4 person-months, intermittent)  
5.  The consultant will have a master’s degree in finance, economic development, or other 
relevant field or equivalent experience, as well as at least 8 years of experience in infrastructure 
financing in the People’s Republic of China. Specifically, the consultant will have a detailed

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
understanding  of  central  and  provincial  regulation  affecting  infrastructure  development  and 
financing. In this regard, the consultant must have a demonstrated work history in the financing 
of provincial infrastructure and be proficient in English. The specific responsibilities of this 
consultant will be to: 
(i)  collaborate directly with the team leader and international consultant to review 
and provide recommendations on outputs related to infrastructure financing, to 
ensure the quality and timely completion of all research outputs; 
(ii)  conduct  research  to  identify  new  and  acceptable  ways  for  the  municipal 
government to generate revenue, such as bond issuances and local taxes, to 
finance specific infrastructure, and oversee and draft a report outlining all findings; 
(iii)  review  the  status  of  government-backed  investment  units  and  propose 
governance, transparency mechanisms, and financial management mechanisms 
in the context of infrastructure financing; 
(iv)  draw conclusions and draft report sections on infrastructure project finance in 
consultation with the infrastructure project finance specialist and the international 
advisor, reporting on innovative financing methods for infrastructure financing as 
per output 4 in Appendix 1, and present findings at the closing workshop; and  
(v)  discuss conclusions with local stakeholders and, based on feedback, draft a 
summary action report on next steps.  
 
D.  Infrastructure Project Finance Specialist (national, 2 person-months, intermittent)  
6.  The consultant will have a master’s degree in finance, economic development, or other 
relevant field, as well as at least 8 years of experience in infrastructure project management in 
the People’s Republic of China. Specifically, the consultant will have detailed understanding of 
how large infrastructure projects are financed and how assets are managed. In this regard, the 
consultant  must  have  a  demonstrated  work  history  in  financing  and  managing  provincial 
infrastructure.  In  addition,  the  consultant  must  be  proficient  in  English.  The  specific 
responsibilities of this consultant will be to: 
(i)  collaborate directly with the team leader and international consultant to review 
and provide recommendations for outputs related to infrastructure financing, to 
ensure the quality and timely completion of all research outputs; 
(ii)  conduct research on current credit appraisal practices and asset management 
approaches in relation to infrastructure financing to identify new and acceptable 
ways for the municipal government to generate revenue, such as bond issuances 
and local taxes, to finance specific infrastructure, and oversee and draft a report 
outlining all findings; 
(iii)  draw conclusions and draft, in consultation with the infrastructure policy specialist 
and the international consultant, a report on innovative financing methods for 
infrastructure financing as per output 4 in Appendix 1, and present findings at the 
closing workshop; and  
(iv)  discuss conclusions with local stakeholders and, based on feedback, draft a 
summary action report on next steps.  
 
E.  Public Finance Specialist (international, 4 person-months, intermittent) 
7.   The consultant will have a master’s degree in public finance, economic development, or 
other relevant field, as well as substantial expertise and experience in public finance and fund 
management  focused  at  the  municipal  level,  particularly  in  (i)  budget  management,  (ii) 
regulatory  frameworks,  (iii)  asset  management,  (iv)  taxation,  (v)  credit  appraisal,  and  (vi) 
infrastructure financing. The consultant will have at least 14 years of experience working on

Appendix 3  13 
municipal finance issues. The consultant should have extensive in-country experience regarding 
municipal and infrastructure finance, in addition to good understanding of central government 
and provincial policies. Proficiency in Mandarin is preferred. The specific responsibilities of this 
consultant will be to: 
(i)  coordinate and work directly with the national consultants on all outputs to ensure 
the quality and timely completion of all research outputs, serving as vice team 
leader; 
(ii)  review  the  municipality’s  current  modes  of  financing,  debt  obligations,  and 
financial structures and draft a summary report highlighting key areas for focus; 
(iii)  conduct research into current international good practice to identify new and 
acceptable additional ways for the municipal government to generate revenue, 
such as bond issuances, service fees, and local taxes; oversee and draft a report 
outlining all findings; and suggest likely destinations for the study tour; 
(iv)  propose recommendations on how to enhance credit appraisals and ratings that 
further promote fiscal soundness and engage investors, and present conclusions 
in a report; 
(v)  review  the  status  of  government-backed  investment  units  and  propose 
governance, transparency mechanisms, and financial management mechanisms 
for implementation in a report; 
(vi)  review the current framework for PPP and determine what further actions are 
needed to encourage further PPP in the city’s infrastructure master plan, and 
summarize conclusions in a paper;  
(vii)  provide quality control and comments on all reports, draft all English versions of 
all reports, and present findings at the closing workshop; and  
(viii)  discuss conclusions with local stakeholders and, based on feedback, draft a 
summary action report on next steps.
